instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B was waterdamaged. It has a green light but wont turn on. I replaced all bad looking components and cleaned the board. I cheched power rails and <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> is missing because the enable is missing too. This enable is created by <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>. <RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR> is only 0.5K Ohm ( but i think that is fine) abnd <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is only 0.7V. I replaced <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> but no change. Diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is 0.223V. Now i am stuck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Fizzl92, post: 32239"]I replaced all bad looking components and cleaned the board.[/QUOTE]

Which were they? This is our only hint to go on, so we need it!

Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> present? <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present? Where was the corrosion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> are present. There was a lot of corrosion on the by the LVDS, T29 circuit, around the SMC and a little bit around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>. Same on the other side of the board but there it was only on some small components between <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> L3895 and <CAPACITOR>C7523</CAPACITOR>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR> being 0.5kohm means it is 500 ohms when it should be 100kohms. 

99% of the time, resistors do not go bad by going down in resistance, they go bad by going up in resistance. Do keep in mind that the resistor is not all you are measuring here. On pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR> is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, and on pin 2 is ground. it is not the resistor you are measuring there. Rather, you are measuring the resistance of every possible path to ground between <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and ground.

So, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground here. There are three potential paths to ground for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>

1) <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>.
2) <RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR>
3) <CHIP>U7940</CHIP>.

If you remove <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR> and you still have 500 ohms to ground, then <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is your issue.

If that is the case, you would have to replace <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>. In this case you would also have to reprogram the BIOS with a clean ME region so it doesn't act all weird talking to the new PCH.

IMO, this is only something to do if you legit have nothing else to work on. You will sink at least another hour into this and $15-$45 for a new chip to fix a seven year old board that may or may not work afterwards, which, if it were on my desk.. screw that. But to each their own. ;)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you very much for the great explanation. I took <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7918</RESISTOR> off the board and still only 500 Ohms to GND. So i try to reflow <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> (i have nothing to lose in a case like this - maybe there was water under it) and i also ordered two new chips so i can try to swap <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> completely... I can only learn from boards like this and i have not so many boards to work on right now... In the case that i get this thing to work how can the BIOS be reprogrammed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Need a programmer to do the BIOS. But it will work as-is for testing purposes. Once the board turns on and has an image the BIOS can be fixed. The TL866 is a good programmer for cases like these.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you. I try to get it to post and get back to you it it turns on. In the mean time i try tp understand the BIOS some more. Today i have no idea how this works, what the ME region is and how it can be fixed/reprogrammed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Finally i can come back to this. The new PCH arrived and i soldered it on to the board. I couldnt belive it but now it turns on. Unfortunately now it beeps 3 times. i tryed a lot of different Ram sticks in both slots but no change. I checked L7330 and it has 1.5 V on it. Now i am stuck again... Could it be bad soldering/IC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Could be bad soldering but could also be a dead CPU, or corrosion pretty much anywhere. Not sure if you should waste more time on this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The bios was from the exact same board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. I have no idea how i can know if the binary is good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
sorry wrong window...

I have not so much to do at the moment so i will give it a try i think. Is there anything i can check or should i try to replace the PCH again? I was hoping that the CPU would be alive as it beeps and the CPU is getting a bit warm - the new PCH is getting warmer than the CPU but still not hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Of course you can try the PCH again. Reballing this one is also an option as it makes it much easier to solder.
